nexttext:
where $\mathcal{L}_{ex}$ defines the coupling to an incoherent radiation field which excites the system from the ground state to the exciton manifold, $\mathcal{L}_{relax}$ describes relaxation rates between the exciton states using modified Redfield theory \cite{Zhang1998,Yang2002}, $\mathcal{L}_{CT}$ defines initial and secondary CT processes using Marcus/F\"{o}rster theory \cite{Forster1965,Yang2002} and $\mathcal{L}_{leads}$ describes coupling of the system to the leads. As explained in the methods section, from this Liouvillian the full counting statistics can be calculated using Eq. \ref{Nth-cumulant} and enforcing both the Coulomb blockade regime such that probability of two electron occupancy is negligible\cite{Bagrets2003}, and the infinite bias limit enforcing unidirectional electron flow\cite{Marcos2010}.

The current counting statistics depends on the induced voltage across a load connecting the states $|\alpha\rangle$ and $|\beta\rangle$ with associated energy gap $E_{\alpha\beta} = E_{\alpha} - E_{\beta}$. As usually done in photocells\cite{Shockley1961}, such a voltage is estimated via a detailed balance condition where the ratio between the steady state populations of the secondary CT state ($\rho_{\alpha\alpha}$) and the `empty' state ($\rho_{\beta\beta}$) is equilibrated at a temperature $T$:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\dot{\rho_{s}}(t)=(\mathcal{L}_{ex}+\mathcal{L}_{relax}+\mathcal{L}_{CT}+%
\mathcal{L}_{leads})\rho_{s}(t)," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mover accent="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><mo>˙</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mrow><mi>l</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
where $\mathcal{L}_{ex}$ defines the coupling to an incoherent radiation field which excites the system from the ground state to the exciton manifold, $\mathcal{L}_{relax}$ describes relaxation rates between the exciton states using modified Redfield theory \cite{Zhang1998,Yang2002}, $\mathcal{L}_{CT}$ defines initial and secondary CT processes using Marcus/F\"{o}rster theory \cite{Forster1965,Yang2002} and $\mathcal{L}_{leads}$ describes coupling of the system to the leads. As explained in the methods section, from this Liouvillian the full counting statistics can be calculated using Eq. \ref{Nth-cumulant} and enforcing both the Coulomb blockade regime such that probability of two electron occupancy is negligible\cite{Bagrets2003}, and the infinite bias limit enforcing unidirectional electron flow\cite{Marcos2010}.

The current counting statistics depends on the induced voltage across a load connecting the states $|\alpha\rangle$ and $|\beta\rangle$ with associated energy gap $E_{\alpha\beta} = E_{\alpha} - E_{\beta}$. As usually done in photocells\cite{Shockley1961}, such a voltage is estimated via a detailed balance condition where the ratio between the steady state populations of the secondary CT state ($\rho_{\alpha\alpha}$) and the `empty' state ($\rho_{\beta\beta}$) is equilibrated at a temperature $T$:

nexttext:
This ratio between the zero-frequency second order current cumulant and the mean current asserts the deviation of the underlying statistical process from a Poissonian distribution. A Fano factor of 1 indicates a Poissonian process without correlations among charge transfer events. While deviations from 1 are interpreted as either super-Poissonian ($F^{(2)} > 1$) or sub-Poissonian ($F^{(2)} < 1$), regimes that can be associated with highly fluctuating or more stable currents, respectively.

In mesoscopic  and quantum systems the Fano factor has proven to be very sensitive to the structure of the state space [ref] as well as on the electron-phonon interactions [ref].  This is precisely what is indicated by the results for the  Fano factor of the current through our photocell device shown in Fig. \ref{fig:noise-voltage}. The analytic form of the Fano factor for our photocell model is too cumbersome. To gain insight into the behaviour presented in Fig. \ref{fig:noise-voltage} it is therefore useful to consider the case of a single resonant level (SRL) \cite{Marcos2010}. The dynamics of this system in the basis $\{ |\mbox{occupied}\rangle, |\mbox{empty} \rangle \}$ is governed by a Liouvillian with matrix elements $\mathcal{L}_{11} = -\mathcal{L}_{21} = \Gamma_R$ and $\mathcal{L}_{22} = -\mathcal{L}_{12} = \Gamma_L$ such that the Fano factor as a function of voltage takes the form
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="F^{(2)}=\frac{\langle I^{2}\rangle_{c}}{\langle I\rangle}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msup><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mi>c</mi></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>I</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
This ratio between the zero-frequency second order current cumulant and the mean current asserts the deviation of the underlying statistical process from a Poissonian distribution. A Fano factor of 1 indicates a Poissonian process without correlations among charge transfer events. While deviations from 1 are interpreted as either super-Poissonian ($F^{(2)} > 1$) or sub-Poissonian ($F^{(2)} < 1$), regimes that can be associated with highly fluctuating or more stable currents, respectively.

In mesoscopic  and quantum systems the Fano factor has proven to be very sensitive to the structure of the state space [ref] as well as on the electron-phonon interactions [ref].  This is precisely what is indicated by the results for the  Fano factor of the current through our photocell device shown in Fig. \ref{fig:noise-voltage}. The analytic form of the Fano factor for our photocell model is too cumbersome. To gain insight into the behaviour presented in Fig. \ref{fig:noise-voltage} it is therefore useful to consider the case of a single resonant level (SRL) \cite{Marcos2010}. The dynamics of this system in the basis $\{ |\mbox{occupied}\rangle, |\mbox{empty} \rangle \}$ is governed by a Liouvillian with matrix elements $\mathcal{L}_{11} = -\mathcal{L}_{21} = \Gamma_R$ and $\mathcal{L}_{22} = -\mathcal{L}_{12} = \Gamma_L$ such that the Fano factor as a function of voltage takes the form

mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="F^{(2)}=1+2\langle I\rangle\int_{0}^{\infty}dt[g^{(2)}(t)-1]." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>I</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><mrow><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

where $\mathcal{F}(\chi,t) = \mbox{ln}\mathcal{G}(\chi,t)$ is the cumulant generating function and the limit $t\rightarrow \infty$ ensures the average is carried out in the steady state. Additionally we assume the system has reached its steady state $\rho_{stat}$ by time $t=t_0$ so we include this instead of the initial state in Eq. \ref{characteristic-fn-dm-form}.
